stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session importing and debugging Biobak’s brand-new Mario model, tweaking N64 combiner settings so it renders correctly (antialiasing, lighting, dynamic palette recolours) and brainstorming a new "light-bridge" set-piece triggered by an arcade button. He also riffs on aggressive cache-level optimisations for the N64 CPU/RCP.

development_findings.summary: Biobak’s replacement Mario model drops from 639 to 595 triangles and cuts TMEM usage by ~39 %, while adding improved shoes, sideburns, eyebrows, cap logo, smoother wings and optional butt-crease.
development_findings.quote: This model here is lower poly and lower resolution than the original Mario model … and it has smaller textures than the original Mario model.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rewrites the model’s material setup: removes unnecessary vertex colours, converts head logo to I4 palette, and writes an HSV-shift routine so power-ups recolour all 16 palette entries instead of a single primitive colour.

To preserve antialiasing and proper lighting, Kaze experiments with two-cycle combiner chains; eventually settles on adding 32 bytes to the head texture so the cap ‘M’ can be done as colour data instead of alpha mask.

Light-bridge concept: a fully transparent walkway spawns when the player hits an arcade button, changes colour as a warning, then fades out. Kaze evaluates gradients, dithering and layer-4 overlays for readability.
development_findings.quote: There needs to be a button where if you press it, the light bridge comes out.

development_findings.summary: Identified Fast64 collision export bug that caused arcade button not to update; fixed by deleting the duplicate object in the level.

Performance R&D ideas: (1) idle thread reads iCache history to pre-fetch next thread, (2) task submission uses targeted hit-invalidate instead of full index-invalidate, (3) OS functions run out of ‘dirty exclusive’ cache lines to avoid RAM traffic.
development_findings.quote: Most of the cool shit isn’t implemented yet. There are three ideas with the cache that I still need to try.

development_findings.summary: Engine source code will be released only alongside the finished game, not beforehand.
Discovered that more than ~5 simultaneous dynamic lights on Mario produce colour artefacts; may cap active lights in hardware build.
Mario’s overall buttons now use a one-cycle reflective setup (texture × shade × shade-alpha) so they appear shiny instead of glowing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows clear pride in squeezing high-end visuals out of 1996 hardware and jokes about ‘polygon budget’ like childhood allowance, reflecting a philosophy of creative constraint.
context_findings.quote: Game studios would never understand— they’d just use a 32×32. We’re doing this on an N64.

context_findings.summary: Stream begins with frustration over Chrome crash and concern about ‘ruining stream stats’, then shifts to excitement when the new model finally looks right on real hardware.
He rejects a novelty dildo sponsorship but is lining up a Manscaped deal and has already drafted lines with Biobak.
context_findings.quote: So far I’ve said no; however, we are probably getting a Manscaped sponsorship. I can talk about my shaved balls on YouTube videos next.

context_findings.summary: Ends early for an appointment at Zeina’s parents, showing a work–life balance boundary.

biobak.summary: Delivered the upgraded Mario model, including detailed changelog (texture downsizing, new folds, CI8/I4 conversions) and offered technical notes on combiner choices.
biobak.quote: 39 % reduction TMEM time … makes the old Mario model look like a beta model.

biobak.summary: Supplied comedic ad lines for the pending Manscaped sponsorship.
Initially opposed adding a butt-crease but allowed Kaze to experiment.
biobak.quote: Too bad for them [the players]— butt crease or not.

zeina.summary: Not active in stream but Kaze signs off early for a visit to her family, indicating personal scheduling interplay with development.

key_stories.title: The New Mario Model
key_stories.summary: Faced with an ageing player model, the team needed something prettier yet cheaper. Biobak rebuilt Mario with fewer triangles and smarter textures; Kaze spent the stream wrestling N64 combiners, palettes and real-hardware tests until the model finally looked ‘insane’.
key_stories.challenge: Improve visual quality without exceeding N64 memory and TMEM limits.
key_stories.process: Biobak optimised geometry/textures; Kaze imported, debugged shading, rewrote palette logic, and negotiated a small butt-crease.
key_stories.outcome: Model runs on real hardware with ~40 % less TMEM and better aesthetics; screenshots earmarked for Patreon.
key_stories.key_quote: This model is lower poly and lower resolution than the original Mario model … and it looks insane.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Light Bridge
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a Portal-style light bridge activated by an arcade button. Visual clarity is paramount, so he debates gradients, dithering and colour-change warnings before disappearance.
key_stories.challenge: Create a readable, timed platform on limited render layers.
key_stories.process: Live-edits textures, tests transparency, and designs button trigger.
key_stories.key_quote: Just trust me that this is fully transparent right now … after you press the switch, it’s gonna change colour and then disappear.

key_stories.title: Extreme Cache Optimisation
key_stories.summary: To squeeze more performance, Kaze sketches three experimental cache hacks—thread prediction, selective hit-invalidate, and RAM-free OS calls.
key_stories.challenge: Overcome N64’s limited bandwidth without redesigning engine logic.
key_stories.process: Outlines ideas during stream; not yet prototyped.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m gonna read the instruction cache and … prefetch instructions into iCache.

open_questions.context: Kaze listed three ambitious ideas but hasn’t started coding them.

open_questions.context: Gradient, dithering and layer-4 solutions were debated but not settled.
